Narrative_Text: Salary expenses are planned with an average annual increment of 5% driven by inflation and market competitiveness.
IT service costs are expected to increase due to higher cloud consumption and cybersecurity investments.
Marketing expenses are front-loaded in the first half of the year to support new product launches.
Retail product revenue in UAE is expected to grow due to stable consumer demand and seasonal promotions.
Automotive sales volumes are conservative due to supply-chain constraints and delivery lead times.
Sales prices are assumed to remain flat, with growth driven primarily by volume.
Material costs are assumed to decrease gradually due to vendor renegotiations and bulk purchasing.
Manufacturing overheads increase marginally in line with higher production volumes.
Salary-related GL accounts should be increased or decreased uniformly across all cost centers when applying workforce scenarios.
IT costs are treated as semi-variable and should scale with business activity rather than headcount.
Revenue adjustments should be applied at the product and market level before aggregation to P&L.
Discounts and returns should be modeled under the same revenue GL but with negative values.
Product cost reduction scenarios should proportionally adjust material and manufacturing cost GLs.
Operating profit is derived as Revenue minus COGS minus OPEX and should not be manually overridden.
The increase in salary expenses is mainly driven by annual increments and selective hiring in IT and digital roles.
IT service costs increased due to expanded cloud usage and system modernization initiatives.
Revenue growth in Retail is supported by higher unit sales rather than price increases.
Automotive revenue remains flat due to conservative volume assumptions.
Product cost improvements are driven by better sourcing terms and manufacturing efficiency.
Operating profit improved due to better cost control despite stable revenue.
